Label your Data, Synthetically

Data scientists often have raw image data and seek to categorize it, based on what the image shows. Well categorized data can become training data for well performing machine learning models.

Historically, people have been needed to categorize images. However, there can be significant costs to do this at the scale required to train machine learning models. How can we reduce this cost without compromising on the accuracy provided by the human eye?

A handoff design of the UX solution.

The Problem

As a data scientist, I am sending all my uncategorized data to costly human annotators to categorize. I want a solution that lets me first send data to a machine learning model to categorize. By doing this I can employ less human annotators and reduce costs.

I was the lead product designer on the project. In addition to UI/UX and visual design, I conducted research and user testing.

Creating good training data requires expensive human annotations.

Initial Discovery

We kicked off this process by gathering sponsored users. These users helped us in the begining to develop user stories, product requirements and initial wireframe sketches. Because we set out to build a completely new offering on our platform, working closely with our sponsored users at every step of the design process was essential for staying focused and on track.

We talked to these users about the work that goes into training good machine learning models. We learned about what kind of models they train or would hope to train and the facets of their training data. We discussed what form their raw data is in and what would be the optimal output once the data is turned into training data.

We used data direct from users in our prototypes to outfit the experience according to their use cases. This helped us ensure that we were building the right feature for them and other teams with similar use cases.

Part of our discovery process was a design thinking workshop to share ideas and emphasize with users at different points in our platform.

Discovery design thinking session.

Ideation

Our goal was to integrate a step into the categorization process in which a user can employ machine learning to predict the categories. With a portion of the data categorized synthetically, the user can reduce the amount of data that gets sent to human annotators, thus reducing costs.

Imagine that a data scientist needs 10,000 images labeled. A machine learning model predicts (with high confidence) that 80% of the images absolutely contain a street sign. The remaining 20% of low-confidence images can then go to human annotators for their expertise.

This approach makes the machine learning training process more efficient, affordable and scalable, without reducing quality.

Expensive human judgments can be bypassed by first asking a machine learning model.

Because the process of getting training data and using it to train a model is complicated, a good amount of time was spent diagramming the experience and the user flow prior to higher fidelity prototyping. We wanted to make a complicated process as simple and painless as possible.

Understanding the active learning loop

Initial page flow sketch

As part of our ideation phase we were able to produce a user flow diagram (shown below). We repeatedly referenced this diagram throughout the design process.

Iterative Prototyping

I first started in Sketch and Invision to create low fidelity mocks and wireframes. The mocks were routinely put in front of our sponsored users to validate design decision and guide our direction. The mocks were iterated on.

Lo-Fi mocks of the Train page, created in Sketch.

Lo-Fi mocks of the Predict/Evaluate page, created in Sketch.

Once we were ready to move the prototype into high fidelity, I continued to iterate in Sketch and Invision, but also began to focus more on some key interactions and visuals. I built in code to do this. This allowed me to quickly experiment, focus on the details of an interaction, and use animations beyond what are possible in Sketch or other design prototyping applications.

This offering was to represent a new effort in AI and ML for our company. We wanted a visual design that communicated that. We wanted our users to know that our platform is smart, trustworthy, and powerful. The visual design was a very important part of communicating this.

See the Pen Model Animations by Joe C (@jcloughley) on CodePen.

I created this visualization with custom code to show the state of the model, from being empty all the way to being fully trained.

See the Pen EeZded by Joe C (@jcloughley) on CodePen.

This code was created to communicate the darg-and-drop animation for the platform.

Handoff

When the customer flows were validated enough for the phase 1 release of this feature, I worked closely with our front-end team to communicate the design and desired interactions. My code snippets helped the engineering team to save time.

Hi-Fi mocks of the Evaluate page

Deep Dive on the Onboarding Experience

Because this feature was such a new offering for our users, and one that is naturally complicated, we emphasized onboarding for the experience. A lot of design work was put into onboarding and this helped to polish my skills in designing onboarding experiences.

Designs for onboarding users to the model training experience.

Designs for onboarding the training and workflow experience.

Outcomes

The feature was initially put into the hands of our sponsored users. We remained in touch with these users to continue iterating and doing bug fixes post-release. Speaking to our sponsored users post-release was just as valuable as it was pre-release and their feedback served as excellent qualitative feedback on the feature.

Lessons

Understanding Power Users

This project brought about extra challenges in getting into the heads of our primary user, the machine learning scientist. In some use cases a designer can become well armed with interaction best practices, a design system, and their own experiences using technology. For this project, I had to go more in depth on how machine learning works, the terminology used and what input and output information is crucial to the experience of creating a machine learning model.

The overhead knowledge required to work with machine learning models appears complicated and technical from my own point of view. This of course isn't the case for a skilled machine learning scientist. I found it challenging to design an experience that meets the user at a level of knowledge I didn't have myself.

To alleviate this, I did my research and made an effort to 'know what I don't know'. Working closely with sponsored users and our own in-house machine learning team was invaluable. Because they were part of the design process, the feature was released with confidence across the board.

Building the Skateboard

This feature was both new and foundational to our platform. Integrating machine learning was something we had not done before. In many ways the feature could be considered a separate product for our company. We knew that this was truly the 'skateboard' we could see becoming the 'bicycle' and then the 'car' in the years ahead. It was a challenge to create new patterns for the experience and anticipate all the ways we would be building off of it in the future.

To meet this challenge, we took a very modular approach to the design and were intentional about how buckets of information were placed. Much of the design is inspired by dashboard concepts that can be rearranged and added to. This initial MVP works with image and text data but we anticipated it working with audio and video in the future. Design decisions were made to accommodate a variety of data types.

All in all, just going into the project understanding that this was an MVP allowed the product and design teams to scope smartly and hold the right kinds of conversations for iteratively improving the feature.

Outcomes

Our sponsored user customers helped us to validate the feature by running A/B tests with their data. The customer was successfully able to set up a model to predict fashion images. When running data through the model, 60% of their total data was correctly categorized and could forgo human judgments. A massive cost savings!
